author: Gabe Cahn
title: 5775 - A Landmark Year for Israel Bonds
text:
As the Jewish year 5775 comes to a close, Development Corporation for Israel/Israel Bonds looks back at a year marked by strong sales, milestone achievements and historic events. On the eve of Rosh Hashanah, U.S. sales so far in the calendar year 2015 are on pace to surpass $1 billion for the third consecutive year.
“5775 was another momentous year for Israel Bonds,” said Bonds President & CEO Izzy Tapoohi. “As we look ahead to 5776, we anticipate that an increasingly diverse number of individual and institutional investors will continue to become stakeholders in Israel’s economy by investing in Israel bonds. In the face of those seeking to weaken Israel’s fiscal standing through illegitimate boycotts and calls for divestment, Israel bonds offer an opportunity to invest in one of the world’s most resilient economies .”
Below are highlights from the past Jewish calendar year 5775 (September 2014 through September 2015).
In November, Bloomberg Business interviewed Israel Bonds President & CEO Izzy Tapoohi. He articulated the Bonds message by saying, "The goal now is to sell the strength of the Israeli economy." Tapoohi added: "It’s an economic narrative that we’re giving today, not a geopolitical one."
In January, Israel Bonds announced that for the second consecutive year, U.S. Israel bond sales surpassed $1.1 billion. Of those 2014 sales, 84 percent were investments of $25,000 and under, and 54 percent were $1,000 and under, highlighting the diversity of Israel bond investors.
Later in January, New York State Comptroller Tom DiNapoli re-invested $50 million in Israel bonds on behalf of the state. DiNapoli had previously, noted that “New York feels a strong connection to Israel, so an investment like this has a double bottom line.”
On January 25, Israel Bonds held its annual International Prime Minister’s Club Dinner in Boca Raton, Florida, featuring a widely-covered address by Israel’s Ambassador to the U.S. Ron Dermer. Ambassador Dermer praised the 600-person audience by declaring, “As purchasers of Israel bonds, you have been true partners in building Israel.” He added that the Bonds organization “helps secure Israel’s future.” In response to the ambassador’s call to stand with Israel, Israel bond investments of over $250 million were announced at the event.
On February 5, Israel Bonds President & CEO Izzy Tapoohi was named to the list of ‘The Top 100 People Positively Influencing Jewish Life in 2014,’ as determined by the Algemeiner newspaper. The list was comprised of diverse, worldwide individuals from all walks of life, included academia, journalism, philanthropy and more. Tapoohi was cited in the business category.
On February 23, the state of Illinois announced a $10 million investment in Israel bonds. State Treasurer Michael W. Frerichs said, “My investment approach is simple. To focus investments in Illinois when possible, but to ensure that we have a diverse portfolio that mitigates risk.”
On March 16, President George W. Bush spoke at the Israel Bonds King David Award Dinner at the Omni Hotel in Dallas, where more than $60 million in Israel bond investments were announced. With over 1,500 attendees, the dinner was among the largest Israel Bonds events since the organization’s launch at Madison Square Garden in 1951.
On March 30, in Chicago, Ambassador Ron Dermer praised Israel’s decades-long relationship with Israel Bonds, declaring to an audience of over 500 that the organization “has helped transform Israel from a small agricultural backwater to a global technological powerhouse.”
In a new video released in April, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu thanked Israel bond investors, saying their investments were “an investment in the Jewish future. It’s a bond between (Israel) and our fellow Jews around the world and the many non-Jews that support the State of Israel.”
On April 29, San Diego hosted Ambassador Ron Prosor, Israel’s Permanent Representative to the United Nations, at the first major Israel Bonds event in San Diego in more than 10 years.
On May 3, Israel Bonds President & CEO Izzy Tapoohi maintained in an op-ed published in the Times of Israel, that the best way to counter the Boycott/Divest/ Sanction (BDS) movement is to invest in Israel’s economy. As he stated, “Investing in Israel bonds defeats the BDS goal of weakening Israel’s economy by doing the exact opposite: helping to keep it strong.”
At the Israeli Consulate’s annual Yom Ha’atzmaut celebration held on May 31 in New York, Consul General Ambassador Ido Aharoni, together with Avi Braf, chief fiscal officer for the Western Hemisphere, accepted a symbolic check for over $1.3 billion representing 2014 worldwide Israel bond sales from Bonds Chairman of the Board Richard Hirsch, President & CEO Izzy Tapoohi, Vice President for Sales Stuart Garawitz and national board members Shira Lewis and Jason Schwartz.
In an op-ed published in the Jerusalem Post on July 11, Israel Bonds President & CEO Izzy Tapoohi took note of Israel’s economic achievements, writing that although the country’s “outstanding success in building a strong economy is often overlooked, the Israel Bonds organization works hard to change that every day.”
In August, Summit County (Ohio) Fiscal Officer Kristen M. Scalise announced that Summit County had invested $1.3 million in Israel bonds, including an increase of $300,000, to bring its total Israel bond holdings to $2.8 million. Israel Bonds President & CEO Izzy Tapoohi said in response, “This investment highlights Israel bonds as significant investments for funds calling for the strictest level of fiduciary responsibility.”
Israel bonds are debt securities issued by the government of Israel. Israel Bonds is also the commonly known name of the Development Corporation for Israel (DCI), which underwrites the bonds in the United States. DCI is a Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) member broker-dealer. The bonds can help preserve capital, diversify personal or corporate investment portfolios, and provide protection from market fluctuations. Israel bonds are versatile securities that currently pay strong rates.
Capital provided through the sale of Israel bonds has helped strengthen every aspect of Israel’s economy, enabling the development of key national infrastructure. Today, expanded ports and transportation networks help facilitate the shipment of “Made in Israel” technology around the world, enhancing national export growth. Capital accrued through the sale of Israel bonds has enabled cutting-edge innovation that saves lives and changes the world on a daily basis.
